DOC.brief_summary: This randomize , counterbalance crossover design , 14 male subject complete two experimental trial . Each trial separate minimum least 12 day ( range : 12-30 day ) . The study aim investigate effect low glycogen availability skeletal muscle molecular response concurrent exercise day .
DOC.brief_title: Molecular Response After Concurrent Exercise With Low Glycogen
DOC.detailed_description: Two experimental exercise trial ; low carbohydrate ( = LOW ) high carbohydrate ( = HIGH ) trial . During experimental day subject complete continue submaximal cycle bout morning follow resistance exercise session early afternoon . During LOW trial subject receive low carbohydrate mixed meal , HIGH trial subject provide high carbohydrate meal . In addition , experimental day subject receive adequate protein beverage . Lastly , protein provide post resistance exercise .
DOC.criteria: Male gender 18 30 year age BMI 18.5 25 kg/m2 Participating regular exercise training ( least 1 exercise session , maximum 3 exercise session per week ) Used different type exercise ( endurance , resistance and/or concurrent ) Willing give blood sample Willing give muscle biopsy No use antibiotic study past month No drug use Suitable vein blood withdrawal Registered generalpractitioner Consumption alcohol beverage le 21 per week No blood donor study No vegetarian willing eat meat experimental day Able present participate test day pre test moment Not employ , intern , work thesis department Human Nutrition Wageningen University Not participate another scientific study ( except EetMeetWeet ) Able participate experimental day en pre test Able speak Dutch Medical condition interfere study outcome ( i.e . cardiovascular disease , pulmonary disease , gluten intolerance ) Systolic blood pressure > 160 mmHg and/or diastolic blood pressure > 100 mmHg Use medication know interfere gene expression muscle ( i.e . statin , fenofibrate ) Use antithrombotic therapy ( marcoumar , sintromitis ) . Diagnosed diabetes mellitus type 1 2 ( Chronic ) injuries locomotor system interfere intervention
